ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Obviously, galaxy formation and evolution. The man himself, Franciscus vdB, wrote the dang textbook and lemme tell ya, it's the best one available presently on the market. I mostly gained a better appreciation for the baryonic processes involved in galaxy evolution, and polished some of my cosmology background along the way.
The physics behind galaxy formation, galaxy-halo connection

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: excellent lectures, great problem sets, an overall good approach to a term project Weaknesses: perhaps too few problem sets, maybe 4 or 5 instead would have been better for the purpose of cementing some of the more complicated topics into our minds Improvement: building a semi-analytical model of galaxy formation would be a great idea, so whenever Frank has time to put together that component for a future rendition of this course, I think it would be very helpful as a 5th problem set. Also, perhaps there is too much material in the class? I feel like we spend a very small amount of time on any one thing in particular, and I probably could have learned more overall if we had focused more time on individual topics instead of covering so much stuff.
Strength- good focus on the physics of structure formation, good overview of the scientific papers in various topics Weakness- should incorporate some relativistic perturbation theory

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Frank's the best lecturer I've had in my time at Yale. To be fair, at face value this isn't the hardest thing to achieve, as the first-year grad course instructors in physics are particularly not good. Frank's class blew all of them out of the water.
Yes definitely. This is by far the best course I have done in Yale Astronomy. Instructors taking other Astronomy courses should learn from the organization and presentation of this course.
